description: From Middle English restoren, from Old French restorer, from Latin rēstaurāre, equivalent to re- +‎ store.

entries.meaning: (computing) The act of recovering data or a system from a backup.
examples: We backed up the data successfully, but the restore failed.

verbs.description: restore (third-person singular simple present restores, present participle restoring, simple past and past participle restored)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To reestablish, or bring back into existence.
examples: to restore harmony among those who are at variance
He restored my lost faith in him by doing a good deed.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To bring back to good condition from a state of decay or ruin.
examples: our fortune restored after the severest afflictions

entries.meaning: (transitive) To give or bring back (that which has been lost or taken); to bring back to the owner; to replace.
examples: The father banish;d virtue shall restore.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To give in place of, or as restitution for.
(transitive, computing) To recover (data, etc.) from a backup.
examples: There was a crash last night, and we're still restoring the file system.

entries.meaning: (transitive, music) To bring (a note) back to its original signification.
(obsolete) To make good; to make amends for.
